title: Left-Hand-Side Expressions
intro:
JS2IL supports the common Left-Hand-Side Expression forms used throughout the test suite (property access, function calls, `new`, `super`, and core meta-property behavior for `new.target` / `import.meta` in CommonJS-hosted scripts).

Notes on scope: the statuses here describe JS2IL's *compiler/runtime behavior*, not a full mechanistic implementation of every spec abstract operation.

entries.notes: Dynamic import() returns a Promise that resolves to CommonJS module.exports. Only string literals are supported as specifiers (compile-time dependency discovery).
Runtime-computed specifiers (e.g., import(variable)) are rejected during validation to ensure all dependencies can be resolved at compile time.
The second options parameter is not yet supported. Using it will cause a validation error.

subclauses.title: Runtime Semantics: Evaluation
subclauses.notes: Returns a Promise that uses the existing CommonJS module loader. Import semantics differ from ESM: imports return CommonJS exports object, not an ESM namespace object.

subclauses.title: EvaluateImportCall ( specifierExpression [ , optionsExpression ] )
subclauses.notes: Implemented for literal string specifiers only. Options parameter is rejected during validation.

subclauses.title: ContinueDynamicImport ( promiseCapability , moduleCompletion )
subclauses.notes: Promise resolution/rejection is handled synchronously using the existing CommonJS module loader. Module loading is not asynchronous.

entries.note: Tag functions receive template object and substitution values
Template objects are cached per call site for object identity, with a bounded cache size to avoid unbounded memory retention in long-lived hosts
Template object contains processed escape sequences
Template object has .raw array with unprocessed strings
Substitutions are evaluated left-to-right as per spec
Template objects are not frozen/immutable yet

entries.feature: Tag function call with template object
NewExpression for built-in Array constructor (new Array()/new Array(n)/new Array(a,b,...))
entries.notes: Supported in the new IR pipeline for global (non-shadowed) Array. Lowered via JavaScriptRuntime.Array::Construct(object[] args) to preserve JS Array constructor semantics.

entries.feature: NewExpression for built-in Boolean/Number constructors as primitive sugar (new Boolean(x), new Number(x))
entries.notes: Supported in the new IR pipeline for global (non-shadowed) Boolean/Number. Lowered to primitive coercions (TypeUtilities.ToBoolean/ToNumber).

Supported in the new IR pipeline for global (non-shadowed) built-in Error identifiers with 0 or 1 argument. When provided, the message is coerced to string. Spread arguments in `new` are not supported.

entries.feature: NewExpression for built-in String constructor as primitive sugar (new String()/new String(x))
entries.notes: Supported in the new IR pipeline for global (non-shadowed) String. Lowered to primitive string conversion (DotNet2JSConversions.ToString).

entries.feature: NewExpression for constructible runtime intrinsics (e.g., Date, Int32Array)
entries.notes: Supported in the new IR pipeline for global (non-shadowed) intrinsic identifiers registered in JavaScriptRuntime.IntrinsicObjectRegistry that are constructible classes. Currently limited to 0â€“2 constructor arguments.
User-defined classes are lowered to direct CLR construction of the generated type, including scope-array wiring for closures in constructors/methods. Spread arguments in `new` are not supported.

entries.feature: NewExpression where the constructor is a runtime value (new valueCtor(...))
entries.notes: When the constructor is not statically known, JS2IL lowers to a runtime dispatch (`JavaScriptRuntime.Object.ConstructValue`) by packing arguments into an object[]. Spread arguments in `new` are not supported.

entries.feature: Property access and assignment: obj.prop / obj[prop] (including computed keys)
entries.notes: MemberExpression lowering supports both identifier and computed forms, and supports both read and write targets. `super.prop` as a *value* (non-call) is not supported; only `super.m(...)` is supported for base-method calls.

entries.feature: CallExpression: user-defined function calls and indirect calls via function values
entries.notes: Covers direct function bindings and runtime dispatch for non-binding callee values (closures stored in variables). Spread in call arguments is supported by evaluating arguments left-to-right, expanding spread values using iterator semantics, and invoking via an args-array dispatch path. Spread in `new` argument lists is not supported.

entries.feature: CallExpression on property access: receiver.method(...) (typed intrinsics and generic member dispatch)
entries.notes: Supports intrinsic static calls (e.g., Math.abs) and dynamic member calls via runtime dispatcher when receiver type is not statically known. Spread in call arguments is supported; typed/early-bound member-call optimizations may fall back to the generic member-dispatch path when spread is present.
Argument list evaluation supports spread elements in CallExpression argument lists by expanding iterables via the iterator protocol. Spread in `new` argument lists is not supported.

entries.feature: Primitive conversion callables: String(x), Number(x), Boolean(x)
entries.notes: Supports the callable form (no new) for global (non-shadowed) String/Number/Boolean. Semantics match JS: no-arg returns default ("" / +0 / false); extra arguments are evaluated for side effects but ignored. Conversions are implemented via JavaScriptRuntime.TypeUtilities (ToString/ToNumber/ToBoolean); Number(undefined) yields NaN (undefined represented as CLR null).

entries.feature: super(...) calls base constructor in derived constructors
entries.notes: Supported for derived class constructors.
`new.target` is propagated through function call/new invocation ABI. Normal calls observe undefined; constructor calls observe a defined newTarget value. Arrow functions capture lexical newTarget.
CommonJS-hosted scripts expose a host-defined import.meta object with stable identity per module URL/path key and a `url` property when available. This is not full ESM module-record semantics.
Supported only for the base-method call form. Property reads/writes like `super.x` / `super[x]` are not yet supported.

entries.feature: Using this before super throws ReferenceError in derived constructors
Optional chaining (?.) for property/index access and calls
entries.notes: Implements nullish short-circuiting for optional member access (identifier + computed) and optional calls, including skipping evaluation of computed keys / call arguments when the base/callee is nullish. Optional chaining on private fields and other less common forms may be incomplete.
